p: As a consequence of shifts in the distribution of suitable climatic conditions for endemic plant species with the reproductive strategies considered here, negative cascade effects on plant-animal interactions, including pollinators and seed dispersers, are expected. With hotter and drier conditions, plant-pollinator interactions may be disrupted by advances or delays in flowering and fruiting phenology [ 12, 13, 92, 93]. In parallel, some groups of pollinators and seed dispersers may face reduced suitable habitat and changes in pupation and emergence times (e.g. [ 38, 94â€“ 97]). The combination of these changes may lead to a reciprocal phenological asynchrony, which would affect reproductive events of both plants and their animal mutualists [ 98, 99]. For instance, interactions between specific pollinators and their respective mutualistic plant species can be disrupted and even extirpated at local scales [ 12].
